articles.title: Aurora Australis paints Hawke's Bay skies with winter hues
articles.author: Rafaella Melo
articles.summary: The Aurora Australis painted the night skies with bursts of orange, red and purple hues in Hawke's Bay, from Te Mata Peak to Puketitiri, in the late hours of Sunday and the early morning. It was the first official day of winter.

articles.title: 'It gave me goosebumps': Aurora Australis delights with a dazzling dance
articles.summary: Aurora Australis was visible from southern Australia on Sunday, June 1. It was visible to the naked eye for about 20 minutes from 8.15pm. The aurora borealis is called aurora australis or Southern Lights in the northern hemisphere. Coronal mass ejection from the sun is forecast to impact Earth on Sunday.

articles.title: Collapsing Swiss Glaciers Aren't the Ones To Worry About

articles.summary: Those most vulnerable to climate disasters live in the poor and fragile nations that ring the Himalayas, such as Nepal and Bhutan, which are at risk of drought and heatwaves caused by climate change.    .   i   in this article.

Some of the shacks in the Calangute-Candolim beach-belt have been toppled or blown down by the strong gusty winds and heavy rain in the last few days.

articles.summary: Ukraine claims to have struck more than 40 warplanes at air bases deep inside Russia. articles.title: Climate debt unpaid
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: There has been a 150% increase in annual direct disaster costs between 1970-2000 and 2001-2020. Total economic losses, including indirect impacts, now exceeds $2.3 trillion. The international community spends 2% of development aid on disaster risk reduction. Agriculture is the most vulnerable sector to climate change, owing to extended droughts and heatwaves. Developed countries pledged $100 billion annually in climate reparations.

articles.title: Pakistan's missed climate opportunity
articles.author: Mirza Mujtaba Baig
articles.summary: In Pakistan, 68% of the population is either unwilling to learn about climate change or completely unaware of it. Pakistan's total carbon footprint is less than 1% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Pakistan could be raking in over $2 billion annually just by tapping into its carbon credit potential. The system for carbon trading is moving at a snail's pace.

articles.author: Teo Blašković
articles.summary: 489 000 people are estimated to have felt light shaking, and 1 592 000 weak. The USGS issued a Green alert for shaking-related fatalities and economic losses. There is a low likelihood of casualties and damage. The predominant vulnerable building types are adobe block and unreinforced brick with mud construction. This is the second M6+ to hit near the coast of Hokkaido since M6.1 on May 31.

articles.title: Four-wheel drivers are thought to be contributing to the decline of a native New Zealand bird
articles.summary: There are only four pipit bird's on the Kaipara and Tawharanui peninsulas. Dunes on beaches including Piha and Muriwai are great habitats for the small, brown and white bird. Four-wheel drivers are thought to be contributing to the decline of the bird.

articles.title: Crisis deepens as glaciers vanish, droughts intensify
articles.summary: There was a glacier collapse in southern Switzerland last Wednesday. Britain's northwest is in drought status after the driest start to spring in decades. A new study warns that more than three-quarters of the world's glaciers are set to vanish if climate change continues unchecked.

articles.author: Gizmodo
articles.summary: As Earth's orbit becomes more crowded, we need more data on how space weather impacts their reentries, researchers say, as they need to know more about the impact of space weather on the reentrant's orbit. The data will be collected from space weather data.

articles.title: Assam Battles Devastating Floods: Rising Waters, Rising Challenges
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Floods and landslides have claimed 10 lives in Assam. The disaster's toll continues to rise as seven major rivers overflow due to persistent heavy rainfall. Rescue operations, including helicopter extractions, are actively underway. The inclement weather has severely hindered road, railway and ferry services.

articles.title: Is N.J. prepared for the next superstorm? Can't trust Trump. Ask Murphy
articles.author: Allison McLeod
articles.summary: Gov. Phil Murphy wants to enact NJPACT – New Jersey Protecting Against Climate Threats. The next round of rules will address how we develop on New Jersey's coast. There is an estimated five feet of sea level rise by 2100. FEMA won't be bailing New Jersey out after the next disaster. New Jersey is one of two eastern states that doesn't have dedicated funding for resiliency measures.

articles.title: Climate activist Greta Thunberg joins aid ship sailing to Gaza

articles.author: The Editorial Board
articles.summary: Glacier loss is a consequence of climate change. It is linked to rising global temperatures and sea-level rise. The Philippines is under threat from glacial loss. Many governments have not committed to act on glacier loss. The UN Secretary General issued an SOS on rising sea levels last year.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu among top heat-risk States in country; warmer nights put people at risk
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu is at risk from extreme heat events. 2024 was the hottest year on record globally and India endured its longest heatwave since 2010. Tamil Nadu ranks fifth among Indian States with high to very high heat risk. Urban centres like Chennai are experiencing significant challenges from rising temperatures.

articles.title: NST Leader: A 2°C warmer Earth?
articles.summary: The Earth is heating up due to the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide reaching the highest level in 800,000 years. WMO warns that the 1.5°C increase above pre-industrial levels recorded last year could become more common. The global temperature could near the 2°C mark in the next five years. Developed countries are increasing their investments in oil, gas and coal projects. Deloitte's "2025 Oil and Gas Outlook" says over the last four years the industry has increased its capital expenditure by 53 per cent and the net profit has risen by 16 per cent.

articles.title: A 2°C warmer Earth?
articles.summary: The Earth is heating up due to the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide reaching the highest level in 800,000 years. articles.title: 40% of world's glaciers could disappear, even with stable temperatures
articles.author: Bojan Stojkovski
articles.summary: Glaciers in the Alps have lost 50% of their area since 1950. Switzerland saw its glacier volume shrink by 4% in 2023, following a record 6% drop in 2022. In Peru, more than half the glacier surface has vanished over the past 60 years.

articles.title: Man-made climate change gave half the world an extra month of extreme heat: Study
articles.author: Divya Danu
articles.summary: Nearly half the world's population experienced over a month of extra extreme heat last year because of human-driven climate change. The Caribbean island of Aruba was the most severely affected, suffering 187 extreme heat days, 45 more than would have occurred without global warming. The report was published ahead of Heat Action Day on June 2, an annual campaign to raise awareness of heat-related health risks.

At least two deaths have been reported, including a police officer who died when a trawler capsized in the Meghna River. The government must provide immediate aid to the affected regions and strengthen its preparedness for future disasters. The monsoon season has just begun.

articles.title: Renowned MIT Professor: ‘Net Zero' Is a Hoax

He dismisses climate doomsday predictions as political theatrics.

articles.title: No Sex for Fish: Women's Survival in Precarious Times
articles.author: Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: Kenyan women's cooperative in Nyatoto, a fishing village, built a thriving business on the basis of collective bargaining power and a shared commitment to self-reliance. Their hard-won gains are under threat from climate change. Flooding disrupts supply chains, making it difficult to access essential drugs, and economic hardship can force women to prioritize immediate needs over healthcare.

articles.title: HRW warns Gulf labourers at risk as temperatures soar
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: UAE, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Kuwait are experiencing high temperatures up to 50 degrees celsius. Human Rights Watch says migrant workers in the Gulf are at risk from extreme heat. HRW urges countries to extend protections for labourers exposed to soaring temperatures. The wealthy Gulf states rely heavily on migrant workers particularly in construction.

articles.title: Tarigami Calls for Relief After Off-Season Snowfall Hits Upper Areas
articles.author: KL News Network
articles.summary: Mohammad Yousuf Tarigami, CPIM leader and MLA from Kulgam, has called for relief measures for people affected by recent off-season snowfall in higher reaches including Margan, Warwan, Gurez, Peer ki Gali, and upper Aharbal. He said the snowfall caused damage to maize crops and livestock, severely impacting residents of these areas. He highlighted the losses faced by nomadic Gujjar-Bakarwal and Chopan communities who depend on seasonal migration and traditional pastoral practices for their livelihood. He urged the government to send field teams to assess damage and provide timely relief.

articles.title: 7,000 Take Shelter In Relief Camps As Heavy Rain Triggers Floods In Tripura

articles.summary: Continuous rainfall across Tripura has caused water levels to surge in several low-lying areas, displacing hundreds of families and forcing them to take shelter in schools and government buildings. More than 7,000 people have taken refuge in 34 relief camps set up across the state to manage the crisis. Red alert remains in effect for West Tripura and Khowai districts, with the India Meteorological Department forecasting more rain and gusty winds.

articles.title: Meteorological Summer Begins: June 1st! ☀️
articles.author: James Carter
articles.summary: The last eight years have been the warmest on record globally. This summer is expected to be warmer than average for much of the United States. It's a harbinger of complex challenges for everything from agriculture to energy grids to personal health. The future of summer is about rethinking how we live, work, and interact with the environment.

articles.title: Canada's summer forecast 2025: Hot and dry conditions a concern for wildfires
articles.author: Anthony Farnell
articles.summary: There is a transition away from a La Nina in the Pacific into a neutral ENSO for the upcoming summer. Most computer models predict a hot and dry summer across a huge swath of North America. There is a risk of heat waves and heat domes in July and August. There will be an active fire season. NOAA predicts an active hurricane season in the Atlantic and a mild summer in Atlantic Canada.

articles.title: So, That Claim Lefties Love About 97% of Scientists Believing Climate Change? Yeah, It Just Got DEBUNKED
articles.author: Sam J.
articles.summary: Cook et al. (2013) and Lynas et.all (2021), both published in Environmental Research Letters, inflated consensus figures to 97-99%. This ignores neutral research and forces scientists to include AGW disclaimers in unrelated studies just to get published. A 2016 survey of American Meteorological Society members reveals the truth: 96% agree climate change is happening and 67% say humans are a major factor.

articles.title: Australia's net zero push is ‘merely a virtue statement'

articles.title: Opinion: Trump's agenda proves to reverse course for planet, not taking climate crisis seriously
articles.author: Timothy Holtz
articles.summary: The first 100 days of the Trump presidency have passed and he remains in denial of the current climate crisis. The data doesn't support Trump's continued claims that the crisis is a hoax. Every month that year ranked among the seven warmest on record. 2025 is already on course to be the second warmest year on record, just behind 2024. The administration's 2026 FY Budget proposal illustrates Trump's commitment to eliminating funding for the globalist climate agenda.

articles.title: Study: Expect more hurricanes like Frances in a warmer world, but with way more rain

articles.summary: Scientists predict future hurricanes in Florida will be wetter and cause more damage due to climate change. Florida 2070 project predicts that if urbanization trends continue, the percentage of developed areas where heavy rains can't seep into the ground will double.

articles.title: Half the world endured extra month of extreme heat

The number of hot days has doubled in almost all countries. Puerto Rico, a territory of the U.S., had 161 days of hot weather, whereas without climate change, only 48 would have occurred.

Three purpose-built emergency shelters are being planned for Antigua and Barbuda. Cabinet has also agreed to improve NODS' communications infrastructure.

articles.title: Opinion – Scorching heat breaking all time records – Len PortPortuguese American Journal
articles.summary: Unprecedented heat has been experienced this May in Portugal and elsewhere around the world. The Algarve has recorded highs of over 95 degrees Fahrenheit. This summer is predicted to break all records, increasing the already extreme risks of wildfires, environmental devastation and community destruction. There is a 70% chance that average global warming between this year and 2029 will exceed the critical 1.5 degrees set in the Paris Agreement. The hope is to keep post-industrial temperatures below the full emergency threshold of 2.0 degrees. This depends on international cooperation and radically reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Heat is the new silent killer across world
articles.author: gulftoday
articles.summary: There were 67 extreme heat events in the world last year and 4 billion people experienced 30 days more of extreme heat. The Caribbean region was the most affected by the extreme events, accounting for 187 days last year. The lower income communities and the vulnerable sections like the older people and those with medical conditions remain most vulnerable to extreme heat, according to the report.

articles.title: Major disaster from three years ago could impact Australia's winters for years
articles.author: Kamilia Palu
articles.summary: On January 15, 2022, an underwater volcano off the Pacific nation of Tonga exploded, releasing 1,000 times more energy than the Hiroshima bomb. It sent 150 million tonnes of water vapour into the stratosphere. The study found it may temporarily alter local climates, including cooler winters in Australia, warmer winters and spring in North America, drier summers over northern Eurasia, and more rain over China's east coast. In Australia, the study found anomalies in surface temperature that could see winters get up to 1°C cooler.

articles.title: Experts: Half of humanity endured extra month of extreme heat due to climate change

articles.summary: In 2024, Austria recorded the warmest year since records began, accompanied by extreme weather conditions such as record summer heat and devastating floods. The climate status report 2024 chronicled the year of extremes and calls for climate protection and adaptation measures. The report is commissioned annually by the Climate and Energy Fund and all nine federal states. It aims to highlight the effects of human-induced climate change.

articles.title: Honourable Spencer Brand Minister Responsible for Disaster Management in the Nevis Island Administration Address on the Start of the 2025 Atlantic Hurricane Season
articles.summary: The Atlantic Hurricane Season for 2025 is officially beginning. Climate change has emerged as a significant factor influencing hurricane activity. NOAA's outlook for the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season predicts a 30% chance of a near-normal season, 60% of an above normal season, and 10% of a below normal season. The agency is forecasting a range of 13 to 19 named storms, 6-10 of which are expected to become hurricanes.

articles.title: SBA relief still available to North Carolina small businesses and private nonprofits affected by drought and excessive heat deadline to apply for economic injury loans approaching
articles.author: Staff Report

Spain's Ministry of Ecological Transition has a plan on the table to build submerged breakwaters to prevent the last of the sand from disappearing.

articles.summary: Pakistan is the most vulnerable country to climate change in 2022, followed by Belize and Italy. The Cli­m­ate Risk Index (CRI) published by Germanwatch ranks countries by the human and economic toll of extreme weather. articles.title: Everything you Know about Geoengineering is Wrong w/ Reinette Senum and Jim Lee

articles.summary: In this episode, Reinette Senum and geoengineering researcher James Lee discuss their pending lawsuit aimed at demanding transparency and accountability on the issue of geoengineering. They break down the real science behind weather modification and clarify the confusion between chemtrails, contrails, aircraft capabilities, and atmospheric intervention.

articles.title: Glaciers in Extreme Danger: Global Warming's Impact
articles.author: James Carter
articles.summary: Glaciers in the Andes, East Africa, and Indonesia are vanishing at an accelerated rate due to climate change. The Paris Agreement's goal of limiting warming to 1.5°C is the best hope for preserving a significant portion of the world's glaciers. Staying within this limit requires drastic reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Warning Signs of an Impending Apocalypse to Watch For (New Update)
articles.author: Freedomsphoenix Readerfour
articles.summary: There are observable trends and events that suggest the potential for catastrophic changes in our world. Environmental degradation, deforestation, pollution, and loss of biodiversity are all symptoms of a planet in distress. Geopolitical tensions can escalate into larger conflicts with global ramifications. The rise of nationalism, authoritarianism, and territorial disputes has created a volatile international landscape.

articles.title: Australian winter forecast to be warmer than usual
articles.summary: Parts of South Australia and Victoria are facing increased risk of winter bushfire due to dryness, says senior meteorologist Jonathan How. He says the risk is due to the dryness.    - Jonathan How, Senior Meteorologist, Jonathan How's Weather Service.

articles.title: Forbes' False Alarm: NASA Claims on Worsening Weather Debunked by Data
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Forbes posted an article titled 'What You Need To Know About Climate Change In 2025' which claimed that global warming is causing an increase in severe weather conditions around the world. Data do not show that severe weather is becoming worse or more common. The general scientific consensus is that the temperature rise should be kept to around 2°C or 3.6°F by 2050.

articles.title: Climate change impacting cyclones, Maha agri: Study
articles.author: Sarfaraz Ahmed
articles.summary: Rising sea surface temperatures are spurring severe to super cyclones in the Bay of Bengal and Arabian Sea over the last two decades. The Arabian Sea experienced 170 hours of cyclones from 1982-2000, which increased to 367 hours (15.2 days) from 2001-21. Cyclone Nisarga (2020) and Cyclone Tauktae (2021) caused over Rs1,000 crore in damages, affected more than 1.4 lakh homes, and damaged nearly 20,000 hectares of farmland in Raigad and Ratnagiri districts of Maharashtra.

articles.title: When our brain feels the heat from climate change

articles.summary: Climate change can have a big impact on brain health, especially for those suffering from neurological disorders. articles.title: A Biologist Spotlights The World's Most Aggressive Bird. Hint: It's Flightless, It's Not The Ostrich, And It's Been Known To Kill People
articles.author: Scott Travers
articles.summary: The cassowary is the third-biggest flightless bird that you need to be careful around in northern Australia or the New Guinea region. Cassowaries are highly territorial and aggressive, especially the females, who are larger and more aggressive than the males. In 1926, a 16-year-old boy was killed by a cassowaries after trying to club it. In Australia, wildlife officers have to develop protocols for safely managing these birds.

articles.title: World Bank Supports Azerbaijan's Climate Transition With Carbon Market Roadmap
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: As climate change intensifies and global carbon emissions continue to rise, the urgency for coordinated international action has reached a critical point. Nazrin Abdul read more here.   .       in the article.  in this article. in this issue.

articles.title: Greta Thunberg, 11 others set sail for Gaza to break Israeli blockade
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Climate activist Greta Thunberg and 11 others set sail from southern Italy on a vessel aimed at breaking Israel's blockade of Gaza. The sailing boat Ma is named after Greta's mother, Ma. It's a sailing boat with a purpose to break the blockade.

articles.title: Opinion: Trump's agenda proves to reverse course for planet, not taking climate crisis seriously
articles.author: Citizen Times
articles.summary: The first 100 days of the Trump presidency have passed and he remains in denial of the current climate crisis. Even before his first term, President Trump began mocking climate change, posting in a blog that "global warming is a total and very expensive hoax" and calling it a "hoax".

articles.title: Canada wildfire: Quebec sends firefighters and water bombers to aid Western Canada as wildfires force ...
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: There are wildfires raging across Alberta, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan. Quebec is offering help to fight the blazes. There is a severe heat wave in the area.      Â   in the province at the moment. It is getting worse.

articles.title: How parents can misinterpret their kids' 'naughty' behaviour
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Wing Siu's daughter moved to Australia. Wing Siu thought her daughter was struggling to adjust to a new culture, but it was a more complex and sometimes "taboo" reality for her daughter. She is now getting used to her new life in Australia.

articles.title: Black-necked stilts gangly member of shorebird clan
articles.author: Kingsport Times-News
articles.summary: Brayden Paulk has moved to Gulf Shores in Alabama. He is planning a Global Big Day of Birding. He wrote to me a few weeks ago about his plans for the event. He sent me an email about his new birding adventures.

articles.title: 'Make it a one-way trip': Greta Thunberg faces heat as she leaves for Gaza
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg is sailing to Gaza this weekend on a humanitarian aid vessel. The 22-year-old will depart Sunday from Catania, Sicily. Critics warn that Israel's ongoing blockade is starving civilians and plunging Gaza into famine.

articles.title: HRW urges Gulf region to protect outdoor workers as temperatures soar
articles.author: The Peninsula
articles.summary: Migrant workers in the Gulf are at risk from extreme heat, Human Rights Watch says. It urges countries to extend protections for labourers exposed to soaring temperatures. The climate crisis aggravates the occupational health and safety catastrophe for the millions of migrant workers exposed to extreme heat.

articles.title: Hurricane season is here, and the nation's top forecaster has an urgent message
articles.author: Usatoday
articles.summary: NOAA predicts at least three hurricanes this season and three major hurricanes in the 2025 hurricane season. No one could have foreseen how traumatic Hurricane Helene would be for so many people in so many states. Getting ready for hurricane season is about knowing that risk and starting the hurricane season ready for what that risk might be.

articles.title: Gulf labourers at risk as temperatures soar, warns rights group
articles.author: The New Arab
articles.summary: Human Rights Watch says migrant workers in the Gulf are at risk from extreme heat. It urges countries to extend protections for labourers exposed to soaring temperatures. The United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Kuwait lie in one of the hot countries. The climate crisis aggravates the occupational health and safety catastrophe for migrant workers there.

articles.title: Warnings about glacial loss remain unheeded
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: Glacier loss is one of the consequences of climate change. Some scientists refer to it as a slow-motion disaster that takes a year or even decades to be felt. There is a global SOS — Save Our Seas — on rising sea levels on glacier loss.

articles.title: HRW warns Gulf labourers at risk as temperatures soar
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Human Rights Watch says migrant workers in the Gulf are at risk from extreme heat. The United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Kuwait are home to a large share of migrant workers. The Gulf states lie in one of the planet's hottest places.

articles.title: Plasma Streams, Coronal Raindrops: Sharpest Ever Images Of Sun Unveiled
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: The corona, the Sun's outermost layer, is mysteriously hotter than the photosphere. It is a phenomenon known as the 'coronal heating problem' and is the cause of the coronal mass ejection (CME) phenomenon on the Sun.
